New Records: The St. Louis Cardinals achieved a historical milestone by defeating the New York Yankees for the first time at the new Yankee Stadium since its opening in 2009 and since the original Yankee Stadium in 2003.
Key Match Events: The game started with the Yankees taking a 1-0 lead in the second inning, but the Cardinals responded with an RBI single by Nolan Arenado and a three-run home run by Brendan Donovan in the third inning.

In the bottom of the eighth inning, Giancarlo Stanton laced a three-run double, bringing the Yankees to within one run of tying the game, but Alex Verdugo grounded out to end the threat. Cardinals closer Ryan Helsley then retired the first two batters and struck out Austin Wells to secure the win.
Post-Match Reflections: The win marked the first time the Cardinals had ever won a game in the Bronx since Game 5 of the 1964 World Series, which was played in the original Yankee Stadium.
The Yankees and Cardinals will resume their three-game series on Sunday, with the Yankees maintaining a one-game lead over the Baltimore Orioles in the American League East.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game's significance was highlighted by the historical context of the Cardinals' first win in the Bronx since 1964 and their previous sweep in the new Yankee Stadium in 2003.
The series continues on Sunday, with the Yankees looking to maintain their lead in the division.
